newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedes want state's alcohol monopoly scrapped - poll.
newsitem.headline: Swedes want state's alcohol monopoly scrapped - poll.

text.p: Two out of every three Swedes want the state monopoly on alcohol sales scrapped but over 30 percent want the state to keep control of alcohol sales, according to a poll published on Thursday.
The survey by research institute IMRI found 63 percent of 1,000 interviewees wanted the monopoly abolished, as recommended this week by a European Court adviser.

However, 33 percent of respondents were in favour of the state keeping a tight grip on sales of wine and spirits. They can be bought only at state-owned shops, Systembolagets, during working hours, five days a week.
Five percent of those in the survey were undecided.
"It is almost more surprising that as many as 33 percent actually are against abolishing (the monopoly)," a spokesman for the Systembolaget chain, Bjorn Rydberg, told tabloid newspaper Aftonbladet.
"After the uproar of the last few days ...I had not expected any other result. The word monopoly has a negative ring to it and I think this plays a large part in this."
The poll found 64 percent expected that ending the monopoly would increase the average Swede's alcohol consumption, which is one of the government's arguments for retaining a monopoly.

However, the European Court of Justice's Advocate-General Michael Elmer on Tuesday rejected the argument that the monopoly was justified on social and health grounds because of the nation's traditionally high levels of alcohol consumption.
He said European Union law was an obstacle to such retail sales regimes for alcohol and he would recommend to a full court in the next few months that the monopoly should end.
The alcohol monopoly is an important source of revenue for the government. In 1996 sales at the Systembolagets reached about 19 billion crowns ($2.5 billion).
